content: Hello,maybe you can help me here?I've been trying to make a BTC transfer from my ledger for a few days, unfortunately without success because the Ledger Live software crashes every time.In the Windows task manager, I can see that the app's energy requirements are very high, I think that's why the app is crashing.I've now tried it with Electrum, unfortunately I can't get any further there either. The stocks were loaded correctly, but if I want to send an amount, a window comes up saying: "Transaction receipts are being prepared... (phase1, 3/349)" I just let the program run, after approx. 9 hours, it was at some point 103/349. after sometime, there was again an error message and the transaction was not executed. Hardware and software are both updated, I tried it on different computers/systems (Mac Book, Windows), unfortunately without success.I wrote to Ledger 2 days ago, unfortunately without an answer so far. I have the suspicion that the programs are overwhelmed with the many small BTC inputs, since I have been getting smaller amounts transferred every day for a long time. Anyone have any ideas on how to get my inventory?

comments.author: LoyceV
comments.body: Quote from: Moeter81 on February 24, 2023, 02:38:03 PM"Transaction receipts are being prepared... (phase1, 3/349)"I haven't seen this message before, but I know a thing or two about consolidating small inputs.I would try this: Enable the Coins tab in Electrum, go there, and select different inputs (hold CTRL to select them). Then use your right mouse button and select Spend. Select 50-ish inputs at a time, and send the full balance to a new address that you own. If you're not in a rush, manually set the fee to 1 or 1.1 sat/vbyte. It will most likely confirm on Sunday if it doesn't confirm earlier.Repeat this until you no longer have small inputs.

comments.author: Lucius
comments.body: @Beparanf, I don't see how Ledger Live on a smartphone would be able to do what the OP can't do on the desktop version - and besides, there's no mention of a model X that has BT, so it's possible that the OP is using an old model S.Quote from: Moeter81 on February 24, 2023, 02:38:03 PMI have the suspicion that the programs are overwhelmed with the many small BTC inputs, since I have been getting smaller amounts transferred every day for a long time.It is very likely that this is exactly the problem, because Electrum has always had a problem with wallets that have a lot of dust transactions. I had a similar problem as you when I first used Electrum many years ago and the way I solved it was to extract the private key from each address and enter it in another wallet. Of course, you have the problem that your main wallet is actually a hardware wallet, and accordingly you cannot see your private keys in Electrum - and not even in Ledger Live as far as I know.The last option would be to try to extract your private keys from your seed, but that would mean that the seed is compromised. You can read more about it here - but I recommend that you use it as a last option, and that you be extremely careful in every step.How to find out your private key by SEED phrase.

comments.author: NeuroticFish
comments.body: Quote from: Moeter81 on February 24, 2023, 04:21:36 PMThat means I go to Electrum and copy the address and send the collected amounts to myself?Yes.First of all, I'd make sure you work with BTC and not mBTC (Tools->Preferences->Base unit).Basically you pick an address of yours that's empty and has no transactions (View->Show Addresses, pick one with tx = 0 copy the address to clipboard).Also View->Show Coins, go to coins tab and select some of them (maybe some 50 at once, but make sure the amount is not too small on them ie ignore those with less than 0.0000055 BTC, if you have such inputs; you can sort the inputs by amount). So, with Ctrl-click you select some inputs, then right-click and press Spend. Only those inputs will be used in the next transaction.You had an address in clipboard, now go to Send tab and send the max amount to this address (CTRL-V). The max amount will be only from those selected inputs.Repeat this a couple of times with the smaller inputs until you get much shorter list of inputs. But not too small inputs.That 50 I've said .. you'll adjust depending on how long the operation takes and whether it fails.Also, if the transaction fee is way too big (even at 1 sat/vByte), then you may want to do the operation again with a different set of inputs, by skipping more of the smaller ones.Quote from: Moeter81 on February 24, 2023, 04:01:54 PMthe nano s has no BTNano S has no BT, but with the right cable or adapter I do use mine with smartphone now and then.However, that's not relevant for now. Electrum for desktop may do the job better imho.
